summary: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] (born Eleanora Fagan; April 7, 1915 – July 17, 1959) was an American jazz and swing music singer. Nicknamed "Lady Day" by [0]'s friend and music partner, Lester Young, [0] had an innovative influence on jazz music and pop singing. [0]'s vocal style, strongly inspired by jazz instrumentalists, pioneered a new way of manipulating phrasing and tempo. [0] was known for [0]'s vocal delivery and improvisational skills.After a turbulent childhood, [0] began singing in nightclubs in Harlem, where [0] was heard by producer John Hammond, who liked [0]'s voice. [0] signed a recording contract with Brunswick in 1935. Collaborations with Teddy Wilson produced the hit "What a Little Moonlight Can Do", which became a jazz standard. Throughout the 1930s and 1940s, [0] had mainstream success on labels such as Columbia and Decca. By the late 1940s, however, [0] was beset with legal troubles and drug abuse. After a short prison sentence, [0] performed at a sold-out concert at Carnegie Hall.[0] was a successful concert performer throughout the 1950s with two further sold-out shows at Carnegie Hall. Because of personal struggles and an altered voice, [0]'s final recordings were met with mixed reaction but were mild commercial successes. [0]'s final album, Lady in Satin, was released in 1958. [0] died of cirrhosis on July 17, 1959, at age 44.Holiday won four Grammy Awards, all of them posthumously, for Best Historical Album. [0] was inducted into the Grammy Hall of Fame and the National Rhythm & Blues Hall of Fame. In 2000, [0] was also inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame as an early influence; the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame's website states that "[0] changed jazz forever". [0] was named one of the 50 Great Voices by NPR; and was ranked fourth on the Rolling Stone list of "200 Greatest Singers of All Time" (2023). Several films about [0]'s life have been released, most recently The United States vs. Billie Holiday (2021).

Life and career.1915\u20131929: Childhood: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] was born on April 7, 1915, in Philadelphia to African American unwed teenage couple Clarence Halliday and Sarah Julia "Sadie" Fagan. Sarah Julia "Sadie" Fagan moved to Philadelphia at age 19, after Sarah Julia "Sadie" Fagan was evicted from African American unwed teenage couple Clarence Halliday and Sarah Julia "Sadie" Fagan's home in the Sandtown-Winchester neighborhood of Baltimore, Maryland, for becoming pregnant. With no support from African American unwed teenage couple Clarence Halliday and Sarah Julia "Sadie" Fagan, Sarah Julia "Sadie" Fagan made arrangements with her older, married half-sister, Eva Miller, for [0] to stay with her older, married half-sister, Eva Miller, in Baltimore, Maryland,. Not long after [0] was born, Clarence Halliday abandoned Clarence Halliday's family to pursue a career as a jazz banjo player and guitarist. Some historians have disputed [0]'s paternity, as a copy of [0]'s birth certificate in the Baltimore, Maryland, archives lists [0]'s father as "Frank DeViese". Other historians consider lists an anomaly, probably inserted by a hospital or government worker. "Frank DeViese" lived in Philadelphia, and Sarah Julia "Sadie" Fagan may have known "Frank DeViese" through Sarah Julia "Sadie" Fagan's work. Sarah Julia "Sadie" Fagan married Philip Gough in 1920, but married ended within two years.[citation [0] grew up in Baltimore, Maryland, and had a very difficult childhood. her older, married half-sister, Eva Miller, often took what were then known as "transportation jobs", serving on passenger railroads. [0] was raised largely by Eva Miller's mother-in-law, Martha Miller, and suffered from her older, married half-sister, Eva Miller,'s absences and being in others' care for [0]'s first decade of life. [0]'s autobiography, Lady Sings the Blues, published in 1956, is inconsistent regarding details of [0]'s early life, but much was confirmed by Stuart Nicholson in Stuart Nicholson's 1995 biography of [0].After attending kindergarten at St. Frances Academy, [0] frequently skipped school, and [0]'s truancy resulted in [0] being brought before the juvenile court on January 5, 1925, when [0] was nine years old. [0] was sent to the House of the Good Shepherd, a Catholic reform school for African-American girls. After nine months, [0] was "paroled" on October 3, 1925, to her older, married half-sister, Eva Miller,. her older, married half-sister, Eva Miller, had opened a restaurant, the East Side Grill, and African American unwed teenage couple Clarence Halliday and Sarah Julia "Sadie" Fagan worked long hours there. [0] dropped out of school at age 11.On December 24, 1926, her older, married half-sister, Eva Miller, came home to discover a neighbor, Wilbur Rich, attempting to rape [0]. [0] successfully fought back, and a neighbor, Wilbur Rich, was arrested. Officials placed [0] in the House of a neighbor, Wilbur Rich, under protective custody as a state witness in the rape case. [0] was released in February 1927, when [0] was nearly 12. [0] found a job running errands in a brothel, and [0] scrubbed marble steps as well as kitchen and bathroom floors of neighborhood homes. Around this time, [0] first heard the records of Louis Armstrong and Bessie Smith. In particular, [0] cited "West End Blues" as an intriguing influence, pointing specifically to the scat section duet with the clarinet as [0]'s favorite part. By the end of 1928, her older, married half-sister, Eva Miller, moved to Harlem, New York, again leaving [0] with Eva Miller's mother-in-law, Martha Miller.By early 1929, [0] had joined her older, married half-sister, Eva Miller, in Harlem, New York.
Life and career.1929\u20131935: Early career: [0] is our person to focus on. As a young teenager, [0] started singing in nightclubs in Harlem. [0] took [0]'s professional pseudonym from Billie Dove, an actress [0] admired, and Clarence Halliday, her probable father.  At the outset of [0]'s career, [0] spelled her last name "Halliday", Clarence Halliday, her probable father's birth surname, but eventually changed her last name to "Holiday", Clarence Halliday, her probable father's performing name. [0] teamed up with a neighbor, tenor saxophone player Kenneth Hollan. They were a team from 1929 to 1931, performing at clubs such as the Grey Dawn, Pod's and Jerry's on 133rd Street, and the Brooklyn Elks Club.  Benny Goodman recalled hearing [0] in 1931 at the Bright Spot. As [0]'s reputation grew, [0] played in many clubs, including the Mexico's and the Alhambra Bar and Grill, where [0] met Charles Linton, a vocalist who later worked with Chick Webb. It was also during this period that [0] connected with [0]'s father, who was playing in Fletcher Henderson's band.Late in 1932, [0] replaced the singer Monette Moore at Covan's, a club on West 132nd Street. Producer John Hammond, who loved Moore's singing and had come to hear her, first heard [0] there in early 1933.  Producer John Hammond, who loved Moore's singing and had come to hear her, arranged for [0] to make [0]'s recording debut at age 18, in November 1933, with Benny Goodman. [0] recorded two songs: "Your Mother's Son-In-Law" and "Riffin' the Scotch", "Riffin' the Scotch" being [0]'s first hit. "Your Mother's Son-In-Law" sold 300 copies, and "Riffin' the Scotch" sold 5,000 copies. Producer John Hammond, who loved Moore's singing and had come to hear her, was impressed by [0]'s singing style and said of [0], "[0]'s singing almost changed Producer John Hammond, who loved Moore's singing and had come to hear her,'s music tastes and Producer John Hammond, who loved Moore's singing and had come to hear her,'s musical life, because [0] was the first girl singer Producer John Hammond, who loved Moore's singing and had come to hear her,'d come across who actually sang like an improvising jazz genius." Producer John Hammond, who loved Moore's singing and had come to hear her, compared [0] favorably to Armstrong and said [0] had a good sense of lyric content at a young age. In 1935, [0] had a small role as a woman abused by her lover a woman abused by her lover's in Duke Ellington's musical short film Symphony in Black: A Rhapsody of Negro Life. [0] sang "Saddest Tale" in [0]'s scene.
Life and career.1935\u20131938: Recordings with Teddy Wi: [0] is our person to focus on. In 1935, [0] was signed to Brunswick by John Hammond to record pop tunes with pianist Teddy Wilson in the swing style for the growing jukebox trade. They were allowed to improvise on the material. [0]'s improvisation of melody to fit the emotion was highly skillful. They's first collaboration included "What a Little Moonlight Can Do" and "Miss Brown to You". "What a Little Moonlight Can Do" has been deemed [0] "claim to fame". Brunswick did not favor the recording session because producers wanted [0] to sound more like Cleo Brown. However, after "What a Little Moonlight Can Do" was successful, Brunswick began considering [0] an artist in [0]'s own right. [0] began recording under [0]'s own name a year later for Vocalion in sessions produced by John Hammond and Bernie Hanighen. John Hammond said the pianist Teddy Wilson-[0] records from 1935 to 1938 were a great asset to Brunswick. According to John Hammond, Brunswick was broke and unable to record many jazz tunes. pianist Teddy Wilson, [0], Young, and other musicians came into the studio without written arrangements, reducing the recording cost. Brunswick paid [0] a flat fee rather than royalties, which saved Brunswick money. "Miss Brown to You" sold 15,000 copies, which John Hammond called "a giant hit for Brunswick.... Most records that made money sold around three to four thousand."Another frequent accompanist was tenor saxophonist Lester Young, who had been a boarder at her mother's house in 1934 and with whom Holiday had a rapport. tenor saxophonist Lester Young, who had been a boarder at her mother's house in 1934 and with whom Holiday had a rapport said, "tenor saxophonist Lester Young, who had been a boarder at her mother's house in 1934 and with whom Holiday had a rapport think you can hear that on some of the old records, you know. Some time tenor saxophonist Lester Young, who had been a boarder at her mother's house in 1934 and with whom Holiday had a rapport'd sit down and listen to some of the old records tenor saxophonist Lester Young, who had been a boarder at her mother's house in 1934 and with whom Holiday had a rapport, and it sound like two of the same voices ... or the same mind, or something like that." tenor saxophonist Lester Young, who had been a boarder at her mother's house in 1934 and with whom Holiday had a rapport nicknamed [0] "Lady Day", and [0] called tenor saxophonist Lester Young, who had been a boarder at her mother's house in 1934 and with whom Holiday had a rapport "Prez".
Life and career.1937\u20131938: Working for Count Basie: [0] is our person to focus on. In late 1937, [0] had a brief stint as a big-band vocalist with Count Basie. The traveling conditions of the band were often poor; the band performed many one-nighters in clubs, moving from city to city with little stability. [0] chose the songs she sang and had a hand in the arrangements, choosing to portray [0]'s developing persona of a woman unlucky in love. [0]'s tunes included "I Must Have That Man", "Travelin' All Alone", "I Can't Get Started", and "Summertime", a hit for [0] in 1936, originating in George Gershwin's Porgy and Bess the year before. Count Basie became used to [0]'s heavy involvement in the band. Count Basie said, "When [0] rehearsed with the band, it was really just a matter of getting her tunes like [0] wanted her tunes, because [0] knew how [0] wanted to sound and you couldn't tell [0] what to do." Some of the songs she sang were recorded. "I Can't Get Started", "They Can't Take That Away from Me", and "Swing It Brother Swing" are all commercially available. [0] was unable to record in the studio with Count Basie, but [0] included many of Count Basie's musicians in [0]'s recording sessions with Teddy Wilson.[0] found [0] in direct competition with the popular singer Ella Fitzgerald. The two later became friends. the popular singer Ella Fitzgerald was the vocalist for the Chick Webb Band, which was in competition with the bandCount Basie . On January 16, 1938, the same day that Benny Goodman performed Benny Goodman's legendary Carnegie Hall jazz concert, the Basie and Webb bands had a battle at the Savoy Ballroom. the Basie and Webb bands were declared winners by Metronome magazine, while DownBeat magazine pronounced the Basie and Webb bands the winners. the popular singer Ella Fitzgerald won a straw poll of the audience by a three-to-one margin.By February 1938, [0] was no longer singing for Count Basie. Various reasons have been given for why [0] was fired. Jimmy Rushing, Count Basie's male vocalist, called [0]'s unprofessional. According to All Music Guide, [0] was fired for being "temperamental and unreliable". [0] complained of low pay and poor working conditions and may have refused to sing the songs requested of [0] or change [0]'s style. [0] was hired by Artie Shaw a month after being fired from the bandCount Basie . This association placed [0] among the first black women to work with a white orchestra, an unusual arrangement at that time. This association was also the first time a black female singer employed full-time toured the segregated U.S. South with a white bandleader. In situations where there was a lot of racial tension, Artie Shaw was known to stick up for Artie Shaw's . In [0]'s autobiography, [0] describes an incident in which [0] was not permitted to sit on the bandstand with other vocalists because [0] was black. Artie Shaw said to [0], "Artie Shaw want [0] on the band stand like Helen Forrest, Tony Pastor and everyone else." When touring the segregated U.S. South, [0] would sometimes be heckled by members of the audience. In Louisville, Kentucky, a man called [0] a "nigger wench" and requested [0] sing another song. [0] lost [0]'s temper and had to be escorted off the stage.By March 1938, the Basie and Webb bands had been broadcast on New York City's's powerful radio station WABC (the original WABC, now WCBS). Because of the Basie and Webb bands's success, the Basie and Webb bands were given an extra time slot to broadcast in April, which increased the Basie and Webb bands's exposure. The New York Amsterdam News reviewed broadcast and reported an improvement in [0]'s performance. Metronome magazine reported that the addition of [0] to Artie Shaw's put the band in the "top brackets". [0] could not sing as often during Artie Shaw's shows as [0] could in Count Basie's; the repertoire was more instrumental, with fewer vocals. Artie Shaw was also pressured to hire a white singer, Nita Bradley, with whom [0] did not get along but had to share a bandstand. In May 1938, Artie Shaw won band battles against Tommy Dorsey and Red Norvo, with the audience favoring [0]. Although Artie Shaw admired [0]'s singing in Artie Shaw's , saying [0] had a "remarkable ear" and a "remarkable sense of time", [0]'s tenure with the band was nearing an end. In November 1938, [0] was asked to use the service elevator at the Lincoln Hotel in New York City's, instead of the one used by hotel guests, because white patrons of the hotels complained. asked may have been the last straw for [0]. [0] left the band shortly after. [0] spoke about asked weeks later, saying, "[0] was never allowed to visit the bar or the dining room as did other members of the band ... [and] [0] was made to leave and enter through the kitchen." There are no surviving live recordings of [0] with Artie Shaw's . Because [0] was under contract to a different record label and possibly because of [0]'s race, [0] was able to make only one record with Artie Shaw, "Any Old Time". However, Artie Shaw played clarinet on four songs [0] recorded in New York City's on July 10, 1936: "Did I Remember?", "No Regrets", "Summertime" and "Billie's Blues".By the late 1930s, [0] had toured with Count Basie and Artie Shaw, scored a string of radio and retail hits with Teddy Wilson, and became an established artist in the recording industry. [0]'s songs "What a Little Moonlight Can Do" and "Easy Living" were imitated by singers across America and were quickly becoming jazz standards. In September 1938, Holiday's single "I'm Gonna Lock My Heart" ranked sixth as the most-played song September 1938. Her record label, Vocalion, listed Holiday's single "I'm Gonna Lock My Heart" as Her record label, Vocalion,'s fourth-best seller for September 1938, and Holiday's single "I'm Gonna Lock My Heart" peaked at number 2 on the pop charts, according to Joel Whitburn's Pop Memories: 1890–1954.
Life and career.1939: \"Strange Fruit\" and Commodore Re: [0] is our person to focus on. Strange Fruit, a song by Abel Meeropol based on his poem about lynching was the equivalent of a top-twenty hit in the late 1930s.[0]'s popularity increased after Strange Fruit, a song by Abel Meeropol based on his poem about lynching. Life and career.1947\u20131952: Legal issues and Carnegi: [0] is our person to focus on. By 1947, [0] was at [0]'s commercial peak, having made $250,000 in the three previous years. [0] was ranked fifth in Billboard's annual college poll of "girl singers" on July 6, 1947 (Jo Stafford was first). Films and plays about Holiday: [0] is our person to focus on. The biographical film Lady Sings the Blues, loosely based on Holiday's autobiography, was released in 1972 and was nominated for five Academy Awards, including Diana Ross for Best Actress. Another film, The United States vs. Billie Holiday, starred Andra Day and was released in 2021. Another film, The United States vs. Billie Holiday is based on the book Chasing the Scream by Johann Hari. Director Lee Daniels saw how [0] was portrayed in The biographical film Lady Sings the Blues, loosely based on Holiday's autobiography,, and wanted to show [0] legacy as "a civil rights leader [ ... ] not just a drug addict or a jazz singer". Another film, The United States vs. Billie Holiday also depicts [0]'s bisexuality and relationship with Tallulah Bankhead. Andra Day was nominated for the Academy Award for Best Actress for Andra Day's performance and won a Golden Globe for Best Performance by an Actress in a Motion Picture - Drama in 2021.Holiday is the primary character in the play Lady Day at Emerson's Bar and Grill, with music by Lanie Robertson. the play Lady Day at Emerson's Bar and Grill, with music by Lanie Robertson takes place in South Philadelphia in March 1959. the play Lady Day at Emerson's Bar and Grill, with music by Lanie Robertson premiered in 1986 at the Alliance Theatre and has been revived several times. A Broadway production starring Audra McDonald was filmed and broadcast on HBO in 2016; Audra McDonald received an Emmy Award nomination. In 2014, Audra McDonald received a Tony Award win. Billie is a 2019 documentary film based on interviews in the 1970s by Linda Lipnack Kuehl, who was researching a book on [0] that was never completed.[0] was also portrayed by actress Paula Jai Parker in Touched by an Angel's 2000 episode "God Bless the Child".

Discography: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] recorded extensively for four labels: Columbia Records, which issued her recordings on its subsidiary labels Brunswick Records, Vocalion Records and OKeh Records, Columbia Records, which issued her recordings on its subsidiary labels Brunswick Records, Vocalion Records and OKeh Records,'s from 1933 through 1942; Commodore Records in 1939 and 1944; Decca Records from 1944 through 1950; briefly for Aladdin Records in 1951; Verve Records and on its earlier imprint Clef Records from 1952 through 1957, then again for Columbia Records from 1957 to 1958 and finally for MGM Records in 1959. Many of [0]'s recordings appeared on 78-rpm records prior to the long-playing vinyl record era, and only its earlier imprint Clef Records, Verve Records, and Columbia Records issued albums during [0]'s lifetime that were not compilations of previously released material. Many compilations have been issued since [0]'s death, as well as comprehensive box sets and live recordings.
Discography.Hit records: Billie Holiday is our person to focus on. In 1986, [0] compiled information on the popularity of recordings released from the era predating rock and roll and created pop charts dating back to the beginning of the commercial recording industry. [0]'s findings were published in the book Pop Memories 1890–1954. Several of Billie Holiday's records are listed on pop charts dating back to the beginning of the commercial recording industry.Billie Holiday began Billie Holiday's recording career on a high note with her first major release, "Riffin' the Scotch", of which 5,000 copies were sold. her first major release, "Riffin' the Scotch", of which 5,000 copies were sold was released under the name "Benny Goodman & Benny Goodman's Orchestra" in 1933.Most of Billie Holiday's early successes were released under the name "Teddy Wilson & His Orchestra". During Billie Holiday's stay in His Orchestra, Billie Holiday would sing a few bars and then other musicians would have a solo. Teddy Wilson accompanied Billie Holiday more than any other musician. Teddy Wilson and Billie Holiday issued 95 recordings together.In July 1936, Billie Holiday began releasing sides under Billie Holiday's own name. sides were released under the band name "Billie Holiday & Billie Holiday's Orchestra". Most noteworthy, the popular jazz standard "Summertime" sold well and was listed on the pop charts of the time at number 12, the first time the popular jazz standard "Summertime" charted. Only Billy Stewart's R&B version of the popular jazz standard "Summertime" reached a higher chart placement than Billie Holiday's, charting at number 10 thirty years later in 1966.Holiday had 16 best-selling songs in 1937, making the year Billie Holiday most commercially successful.[citation needed] It was in 1937 that Billie Holiday scored Billie Holiday's sole number one hit as a featured vocalist on the available pop charts of the 1930s, "Carelessly". the popular jazz standard "Summertime", was also recorded by Ray Noble, Glen Gray and Fred Astaire, whose rendering was a bestseller for weeks.[citation needed] Billie Holiday's version ranked 6 on the year-end single chart available for 1937.In 1939, Billie Holiday recorded Billie Holiday's biggest selling record, "Strange Fruit" for Commodore, charting at number 16 on the available pop charts for the 1930s.In 1940, Billboard began publishing Billboard's modern pop charts, which included the Best Selling Retail Records chart, the precursor to the Hot 100. None of Holiday's songs placed on the modern pop charts, partly because Billboard only published the first ten slots of the modern pop charts in some issues. Minor hits and independent releases had no way of being spotlighted."God Bless the Child", which went on to sell over a million copies, ranked number 3 on Billboard's year-end top songs of 1941.On October 24, 1942, Billboard began issuing its R&B charts. Two of Holiday's songs placed on its R&B charts, "Trav'lin' Light" with Paul Whiteman, which topped the chart, and "Lover Man", which reached number 5. "Trav'lin' Light" with Paul Whiteman, which topped the chart also reached 18 on Billboard's year-end chart.
